title: internetional
author: internetional
content: LiPa (https://lipa.swiss) stands for Lightning Payment. This is a wallet for payment, not just for transfers. The wallet exists in iOS version only. Now it is open in testflight mode. The concept of the wallet is like one of Breez, Phoenix or Mutiny: you receive your first money and pay 5K sats for opening a channel. But then … you cannot do anything with your money except spending in a point of sales supporting LiPa. There is a “Send” button, but in my case the result of pressing it is very strange for a non-custodial wallet: So, I may create invoices and receive payments via LN, I may pay to LiPa business users, but I am not allowed to send my money to anyone I want outside the LiPa ecosystem.Be careful with this wallet. At least now, when it is still in testflight mode. Maybe, the devs are going to open the access to the “Send” button later, but now it’s absent, and you don’t know about this until you try to send sats.

comments.author: sigismallz
comments.body: Quote from: Yamane_Keto on July 31, 2023, 08:38:53 AMWe can say that they claim to be a non-custodial wallet, but without the code being open source, we cannot verify these claims and some actions such as banning service for a specific country or not possible to send except under certain conditions that contradict the principle that you have access to the private key aka custodial wallet.This service is centralized and there are other alternatives to the Lightning Network, so there is no reason to use them.I don't know what language the site is written in, so I couldn't understand them.@internetional you have a funny avatar  In this early stage of the lipa wallet, not all parts of the App are open source. The Lightning node and which is also the core of the App is however open source: We call it lipa-lightning-lib and it is open source and available on GitHub: https://github.com/getlipa/lipa-lightning-libIt is responsible for all Bitcoin things, including the cryptography and key management needed for a non-custodial Wallet. The lipa-lightning-lib heavily relies on the Lightning Dev Kit: https://lightningdevkit.org/A couple of helper libraries are also open source (https://github.com/getlipa/wild and https://github.com/getlipa/perro). We've also got the open-sourcing of the mobile wrappers (UI) on our roadmap, which is the last missing piece for the App to be fully open source.  We are aware that transparency (also through disclosing our source code) is a key factor for wallet security and privacy and are working hard to build the lipa Wallet the right way, following the Bitcoin ethos.Please note that the sending functionality is not actually banned by region. What happened here was just a unfortunate mistake regarding the wording we chose for a feature that is yet to be delievered. For that reason, the send Button has been removed entirely in the current version to prevent confusion: Instead you can use the pay button to send Sats to any other wallet of your choosing.

comments.author: Pmalek
comments.body: There are contradictory statements between the information on your website and in your FAQ section. Regarding fees, your website states:QuoteWith Lipa there are no fees for the use of the app and for receiving transactions. We only charge 0.98% for the exchange of Bitcoin into your currency (EUR, CHF)https://lipa.swiss/en/for-business.htmlBut then on the FAQ we have this:QuoteHow much will it cost me to use lipa?There are no basic fees. Costs are incurred through the use of lipa. We charge the minimum fee of 0.98% of the invoice amount of each transaction.https://lipa.swiss/en/faq.htmlIn the first example, it sounds like all wallet operations are free, and users only pay when exchanging BTC into fiat. But in the second example, you say you charge a minimum fee of 0.98% from the invoiced amount. That also means that the fees can be higher. How much higher? How exactly does your fee system work?The business version of your app is available for Android, while the regular one still isn't. Could Android users (if they wanted) use the Business version in the meantime, and what pros/cons would there be for doing that?If you claim certain parts of your code is open-source, I think there should be a link on your website to the GitHub page. I don't see it among the social media buttons or elsewhere. I see that you posted a link in one of your previous posts, but you should link to it on the website as well.
